Problems don’t age well, and we may soon find out what happens when we let them pile up.
 
Next week, Congress is set to leave for a two and a half week vacation. This is insane. Lock us in on the House floor and make us hash out these issues until we reach a bipartisan solution.

html: If we can’t reach an agreement, existing law would cut defense spending by more than $70 billion. And since we did not reach a solution to the border crisis during the government shutdown, border security is likely to complicate an already-messy negotiation later this year.

html: By offering a bill instead of a budget resolution, my Democratic colleagues on the Budget Committee are neglecting to consider the larger fiscal picture. This is a big problem because there is a looming debt ceiling and budget cap fight, and no one is on the same page.
text: By offering a bill instead of a budget resolution, my Democratic colleagues on the Budget Committee are neglecting to consider the larger fiscal picture. This is a big problem because there is a looming debt ceiling and budget cap fight, and no one is on the same page.

html: The Budget Committee is marking up a bill today that would raise budget caps for the next two years and dedicate $733B for defense in FY2020. That’s less than the president's $750B request and applies a dollar-for-dollar increase for defense and non-defense spending.
text: The Budget Committee is marking up a bill today that would raise budget caps for the next two years and dedicate $733B for defense in FY2020. That’s less than the president's $750B request and applies a dollar-for-dollar increase for defense and non-defense spending.

html: The appropriators released a 1100+ page omnibus bill after midnight today. We suspended (i.e. violated) the rules to vote on it less than 24 hours later with no real deliberation or debate.
text:
The appropriators released a 1100+ page omnibus bill after midnight today. 

We suspended (i.e. violated) the rules to vote on it less than 24 hours later with no real deliberation or debate.

html: Why do we have a Congress? Presumably we have a Congress to deliberate, debate, and legislate. When it comes to border security, Congress has done none of these things.
text:
Why do we have a Congress?

Presumably we have a Congress to deliberate, debate, and legislate. When it comes to border security, Congress has done none of these things.

html: A top-down approach to policy problems does not work. We shouldn’t be surprised when this process results in a last second vote on legislation that we have little to no time at all to evaluate.pic.twitter.com/LPRVxpAZqU

text:
Later tonight we’ll be voting on a 1,159 page bill that we had less than 24 hours to read. This is bad process. And as we’ve learned the hard way, bad process leads to bad policy.

html: Lesson #3 is simple: Problems don’t age well. That’s true in life and particularly true in politics. We can’t punt the problem of border security to the next generation. So let’s work together over these next two weeks with a sense of urgency to fix it.
text:
Lesson #3 is simple: Problems don’t age well. 

That’s true in life and particularly true in politics. We can’t punt the problem of border security to the next generation. So let’s work together over these next two weeks with a sense of urgency to fix it.

html: It's no surprise when this process results in a hurried vote on a bill that we had no opportunity to amend. We should instead work from the ground up, starting with the relevant committees & ordinary members. This will increase the likelihood of achieving long-lasting policies.
text:
It's no surprise when this process results in a hurried vote on a bill that we had no opportunity to amend. 

We should instead work from the ground up, starting with the relevant committees & ordinary members. This will increase the likelihood of achieving long-lasting policies.

html: Lesson #2: A top-down approach to policy problems does not work. It seems we routinely let the President and the most powerful members of Congress negotiate in secret, while the rest of us wait for white smoke to emerge from the White House chimney.
text:
Lesson #2: A top-down approach to policy problems does not work.

It seems we routinely let the President and the most powerful members of Congress negotiate in secret, while the rest of us wait for white smoke to emerge from the White House chimney.

html: In other words, the debate over border security is the best kind of debate to have. It’s not about irreconcilable, abstract principles. It’s about specific requirements that we can measure in terms of geography, human resources and cost.
text: In other words, the debate over border security is the best kind of debate to have. It’s not about irreconcilable, abstract principles. It’s about specific requirements that we can measure in terms of geography, human resources and cost.

html: Perhaps Democrats disagree with this proposal. But assuming everyone agrees on the long-term goal of gaining 100 percent operational control of the border, then the only question is: how do we do it more effectively? What is the right mix of barriers, technology and people?

html: When it comes to border security, we’re not talking about irreconcilable differences. We’re talking about something knowable: what does $1.5 billion vs. $5 billion get you in terms of border security? We should be locked-in on the House & Senate floors until we figure it out.
text:
When it comes to border security, we’re not talking about irreconcilable differences. We’re talking about something knowable: what does $1.5 billion vs. $5 billion get you in terms of border security? 

We should be locked-in on the House & Senate floors until we figure it out.

html: Tonight's CR vote was the worst possible outcome: 1. It punted the border security issue to February. 2. We still haven't even had a debate on the issue. 3. It continues the same bad process that got us into this mess. Let's find a long-term solution to secure our border.pic.twitter.com/Dt0GeQvYE9
text:
Tonight's CR vote was the worst possible outcome:

1. It punted the border security issue to February.
2. We still haven't even had a debate on the issue.
3. It continues the same bad process that got us into this mess.

Let's find a long-term solution to secure our border.pic.twitter.com/Dt0GeQvYE9

html: We need a long-term strategy in Syria that advances our interests and protects our allies. Virtual presence will translate into actual absence. I'm afraid we will soon regret a hasty retreat.
text: We need a long-term strategy in Syria that advances our interests and protects our allies. Virtual presence will translate into actual absence. I'm afraid we will soon regret a hasty retreat.

html: Long-term, I’m concerned about the growing Russian military presence in Syria. If we are not careful, Russia could grow its new naval and air bases to threaten our access in the eastern Mediterranean, and perhaps even Suez.
text: Long-term, I’m concerned about the growing Russian military presence in Syria. If we are not careful, Russia could grow its new naval and air bases to threaten our access in the eastern Mediterranean, and perhaps even Suez.

html: The administration is right to want to roll back Iranian influence in the region, but we can’t do that if we aren’t engaged on the ground in support of our allies. Handing Syria to the Assad/Putin/Iranian axis is no way to bring stability to Syria, or to the region.
text: The administration is right to want to roll back Iranian influence in the region, but we can’t do that if we aren’t engaged on the ground in support of our allies. Handing Syria to the Assad/Putin/Iranian axis is no way to bring stability to Syria, or to the region.

html: President Obama found out the hard way that withdrawing unilaterally from Middle East hotspots tends to leave power vacuums that are filled by actors that do not share our interests. In the case of our exit from Iraq, we only ended up emboldening Iran.

html: We’ll see what happens in 60 days. But for now, all Americans should take heart that we are holding Russia accountable for its actions and paving the way for a more secure future in the Indo-Pacific, all while working closely with our allies.
text: We’ll see what happens in 60 days. But for now, all Americans should take heart that we are holding Russia accountable for its actions and paving the way for a more secure future in the Indo-Pacific, all while working closely with our allies.

html: Just as importantly, our @NATO allies have released a unanimous statement concurring with the administration’s assessment of Russia’s material breach. So let’s be clear: this is not a unilateral step away from arms control. This is a consensus finding coordinated with our allies.
text: Just as importantly, our @NATO allies have released a unanimous statement concurring with the administration’s assessment of Russia’s material breach. So let’s be clear: this is not a unilateral step away from arms control. This is a consensus finding coordinated with our allies.

html: Today, @SecPompeo delivered an unequivocal finding that Russia’s actions constitute a material breach of INF. If Russia fails to verifiably return to its obligations under the agreement, in 60 days, the US will suspend its compliance with the treaty.
text: Today, @SecPompeo delivered an unequivocal finding that Russia’s actions constitute a material breach of INF. If Russia fails to verifiably return to its obligations under the agreement, in 60 days, the US will suspend its compliance with the treaty.

html: Recognizing these realities, my amendment to the FY19 NDAA gave @POTUS until January to make a final determination of whether Russia is in material breach of its INF obligations. In the event of a positive material breach determination, the amendment set a path to exit the treaty
text: Recognizing these realities, my amendment to the FY19 NDAA gave @POTUS until January to make a final determination of whether Russia is in material breach of its INF obligations. In the event of a positive material breach determination, the amendment set a path to exit the treaty

html: Meanwhile, China has never been part of the treaty and has amassed an arsenal over 2,000 ballistic and cruise missiles—about 95% of which fall under INF ranges. These missiles are far cheaper than our ships and planes, meaning we are increasingly priced out of the competition.
text: Meanwhile, China has never been part of the treaty and has amassed an arsenal over 2,000 ballistic and cruise missiles—about 95% of which fall under INF ranges. These missiles are far cheaper than our ships and planes, meaning we are increasingly priced out of the competition.

html: Although we did not realize it at the time, we know from former Obama administration officials that Russia began testing INF-prohibited ground-launched cruise missiles in 2008. Every year since 2014, the @StateDept has found Russia to be in violation of its INF obligations.
text: Although we did not realize it at the time, we know from former Obama administration officials that Russia began testing INF-prohibited ground-launched cruise missiles in 2008. Every year since 2014, the @StateDept has found Russia to be in violation of its INF obligations.

html: This may negatively impact bottom lines, but the government & private sector must get on the same page. Throughout our history, American industry has been central to the security of our nation--and our prosperity has depended on our security. It is time we recapture that spirit.
text: This may negatively impact bottom lines, but the government & private sector must get on the same page. Throughout our history, American industry has been central to the security of our nation--and our prosperity has depended on our security. It is time we recapture that spirit.

html: I'd argue that moving forward, an important part of corporate social responsibility should be evaluating how business partnerships with authoritarian nations could contribute to oppression abroad or put American lives at risk.
text: I'd argue that moving forward, an important part of corporate social responsibility should be evaluating how business partnerships with authoritarian nations could contribute to oppression abroad or put American lives at risk.

html: Silicon Valley has been at the forefront of corporate social responsibility policies. In light of how countries like the PRC are using technological innovation for highly unethical purposes, it is time to rethink what corporate social responsibility includes.
text: Silicon Valley has been at the forefront of corporate social responsibility policies. In light of how countries like the PRC are using technological innovation for highly unethical purposes, it is time to rethink what corporate social responsibility includes.

html: Another example: the @WSJ just published an important story about @nvidia's highly questionable partners in the PRC, including some involved in the mass oppression in Xinjiang. https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-silicon-valley-tech-leader-walks-a-high-wire-between-the-u-s-and-china-1542650707 …

html: Take @Google. Even more than developing a censored search engine, I'm concerned about its AI research center in China. At best, the CCP will use AI to expand its control over the lives of its citizens. At worst, it may one day be used in combat against US forces or our allies.

html: It's no surprise that as the volume of negative ads increases, our political environment becomes more toxic. It can be easy to respond in kind when you're faced with negativity. But this only exacerbates the hostility and vitriol in our politics.
text: It's no surprise that as the volume of negative ads increases, our political environment becomes more toxic. It can be easy to respond in kind when you're faced with negativity. But this only exacerbates the hostility and vitriol in our politics.

html: And over $3 billion was spent on TV/radio ads, setting the record for a midterm election. html: Whatever the answers, what is clear is that demands on the Navy are only set to grow in the future. Let's not let perfect be the enemy of good. Let's get building. The Navy the nation needs is the biggest one it can possibly build—now.
text: Whatever the answers, what is clear is that demands on the Navy are only set to grow in the future. Let's not let perfect be the enemy of good. Let's get building. The Navy the nation needs is the biggest one it can possibly build—now.

html: What's the Navy been up to in the six months since we first heard about a new assessment in March? And why will the new assessment not be ready until more than a year after the new defense strategy?
text: What's the Navy been up to in the six months since we first heard about a new assessment in March? And why will the new assessment not be ready until more than a year after the new defense strategy?

html: The problem is the way in which this is happening. In March, the Navy told us that they were planning on conducting a new force structure assessment. Then, the Navy re-announced a forthcoming new assessment just last month, due “some time” in 2019.
text: The problem is the way in which this is happening. In March, the Navy told us that they were planning on conducting a new force structure assessment. Then, the Navy re-announced a forthcoming new assessment just last month, due “some time” in 2019.

html: Back in December 2016, the Navy released a force structure assessment that called for a 355-ship fleet. Given the change in administration and defense strategy since then, it makes sense that the Navy wants to review the size and composition of its future fleet.
text: Back in December 2016, the Navy released a force structure assessment that called for a 355-ship fleet. Given the change in administration and defense strategy since then, it makes sense that the Navy wants to review the size and composition of its future fleet.

text:
4. Forecasts predict that America’s population will grow to 400 million by 2051.

In order to both safely and efficiently move the increasing number of people and goods in the U.S., we must encourage innovation and utilize new @Transport technologies.

html: Why is this @Transport hearing so important? Consider these stats: 1. The movement of freight is expected to increase 40% over the next 30 years. 2. US trade volume is expected to double by 2021. 3. In terms of highway usage, vehicle miles traveled will increase 20% by 2035.
text:
Why is this @Transport hearing so important? Consider these stats:

1. The movement of freight is expected to increase 40% over the next 30 years.
2. US trade volume is expected to double by 2021.
3. In terms of highway usage, vehicle miles traveled will increase 20% by 2035.

html: Just sat down for a @Transport hearing on innovative technologies being used on our highways and public transit systems. html: On June 6, 1944, 160,000+ Allied troops landed at #Normandy, a heavily fortified stretch of French coastline to initiate #DDay. More than 10,000 Allied soldiers were killed or wounded, but by day's end, the Allies had begun liberating Europe. #DDay74 #TodayinHistorypic.twitter.com/3WHRYURA4d
